prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

spanGrp.span: One day a man emigrated. He was married, recently married. He emigrated and worked abroad.
I mean, he was working abroad for 15 to 20 years. Let’s say, he left from here and worked in Adana, Antep or Mersin. I mean, somewhere far away from Urfa.
He went away from Urfa for work. In former times people went on foot as there was no transportation, they went on foot.
After he had left, he was working for 20 years abroad leaving his wife here. He had married and then he left.
He earned 3,000 aqče of money, the aqče, the currency of the former times, one aqče would equal, let’s say
one million nowadays, or one thousand, three… ancient money. Let’s say in your currency it would equal 3,000 euro;
I mean he had earned 3,000 euro in these twenty years.
After he had earned that he said, “It is enough, I miss my wife, I want to see my wife, I miss her, really I miss her.”
He got himself ready and wanted to return to his homeland. He took his money, his aqčas and set off towards his homeland.
While he was on his way back, let’s say, he was returning from Adana, Tarsus, Ceyhan, he suddenly saw some people standing on the road, let’s say.
In former times, people used to travel by carriage or another vehicle or on foot. Then he saw somebody and people gathering around him.
One said, “I sell advice for money, I sell advice for money, I sell advice.”
He came and said, “What kind of advice do you sell? What advice?” He said, “I sell one advice for 1,000 aqče”

He said (to himself), “I have 3,000 aqče, I wonder what kind of advice this is!” I will give him 1,000 lira; I will buy from him an advice for 1,000 aqče. He stopped by him and said, “What is it, brother?” He said, “Here you are, give me 1,000 and I’ll sell you one advice.”
He gave him 1,000. What he said, its meaning in Arabic is, “Whatever fate wills will happen; whatever fate wills will happen. I mean, what is written in destiny that will happen.”
He said, “Is it that what you sold to me? I already know that!” He said, “(But) I sell it for money.”

And he took the 1,000 from him. The other went away and said: “One thousand is gone.” While he was walking along his way, he saw again some people, let’s say, when he reached Antep again some people gathered around someone who said, “I sell advice for money.”
He came nearer again and said, “Maybe this one’s advice is better than that of the other one.”
“Brother, for how much do you sell the advice?” He said, “Well, I sell advice for 1,000 aqče.” For the 1,000 aqče of the former times.
He said, “What is it?” He said, “No, give me the money first, then I’ll tell you. Give me the aqčes first!”

He gave him 1,000 aqče and said, “What is it?” He said, “The good thing is what the heart desires; the heart, what the heart desires is the good thing. That means, whatever the heart desires this is the good thing.” Its meaning (lit. translation):
What the heart desires is the good thing” He said, “Is it that what you are talking about? I already know it!” He said, “(But) I sell it for money, my brother.”
He said: “These 1,000 are also gone, they are away.”
He kept on walking and again came across someone; he saw him in Suruç, let’s say, in the province of Urfa; he got close to Urfa.
“I sell advice, I sell advice, I sell advice!” He said, “Isn’t there anything else on this road but advice? Everyone is selling advice
there is no (one who sells) tomato, orange, pepper, or sugar. Everyone is selling advice; they have nothing but advice.”
“Brother, what do you sell?” He said, “Well, I sell advice for 1,000 aqče as well”
He said, “My Lord, the first 2,000s are gone and now only this 1,000 is left. Maybe this guy fears (God) and his advice is useful.
I want to buy it from him. My brother, take this 1,000 and tell me your advice!”
He said, “Everything has its time, that means, everything has its time and nothing should come in a hurry. That means patience is all and everything has its time and nothing should come in a hurry.”
He said, “Is this your advice?” He said, “Yes!” He said, “I already know it!” He said, “Well, brother, but I sell it for money.”
He took the money from him, and the guy was left without anyyyyy money.
“O my patient God!“ He has come back to his homeland but was still walking on the road. While he was walking on the road, he saw something.

While he was on his way, he saw a well, a place, he saw a gathering of people (at) some water; people who had gathered around the well like that, like a cistern; something was inside of it, we use to call it, the Turks say dragon, a lindworm, something big, a beast, a dragon, a big dragon and people were standing around.

They had gathered around it and no one was dared to get down. Then the pasha said, “Is there someone here who can get in the well and bring the thing out?” Let’s say, “Can, someone get the dragon out from inside or kill it or take out a girl who fell down there. Whoever gets the girl out from there I will give him as much as he wants.
Whoever brings the dragon out from inside I will give him as much as gold he wants!” No one dared to get down. Whoever gets in, gets eaten and killed by the dragon.
Well, this guy came, stopped, and asked an old man, “What is the gathering here?” He said, “The padishah, the pasha says, “Whoever goes down, I will give him whatever he wants.”
The guy had nothing left, I mean, as the Turks say: “He has nothing to lose”, I mean the aqčas were gone. He had come hungry. He had left with nothing and he came back with nothing.

He had left naked and came naked. Well, he asked, “What is the matter?” They said, “There is a dragon inside and no one dares (to go down). It has a girl and no one dares to go down to to get it out or kill it
in order to rescue the girl”. Then he said, “Well, I have nothing left to lose. I want to inside.” When he stepped in, he went down to it. When he went down, the dragon talked to him.
He stood next ot it and the dragon said to him, “Why did you come? What do you want?” He said, “I want nothing at all.” The dragon said: “I want to ask you something.”

The dragon said, “How come that you came here? None of these people dared to enter, that means, you are really self-confident, strong, I mean, you are a brave man, šiǧīʕ means brave like a warrior. Aren’t you scared?” He said, “Well, I just stepped in.” It said, “Fine!” Then the dragon said, “I want to ask you about something. If you know it, I will get out of here, I will give you whatever you want, I will get out of here, out from this well.”

He took the girl and said, “Go ahead, ask me!” It said: “Is this girl better or this toad?” He had a toad and the daughter of the padishah or I don’t know who had fallen down there. The one who had said, “Who can get my daughter out …” It said, “Is this toad better or is this girl better?”
The guy started to think and think. When he had entered the well, he had said, “Whatever fate wills will happen.” This was the first advice. The one from the first time.

He looked and said: “Well, even the fool knows that this girl is better” He said that to himself, if I say it like this, he won’t harm me, and said: “Brother, the heart, I mean, the heart, what the heart desires is the good thing” He said: “How?” He said: “What the heart desires, my heart desires the ʕugurruga. The one that the heart desires is the good one.”
The dragon continued, “Well, you are right. Fine, brother, here you are, I will give you the girl and get out from here.”

He went up and the king said: “Brother, you can take as much gold as you want, just take it!” He came and gave him as much gold as he desired. He took gold more than 3,000 aqčes (he had before). This was the second advice.

He took the gold and went on. He continued his way home. When he arrived home at night, he looked at his wife, he entered the house and looked at his wife, who had someone young sleeping in her arms, a young man.

The young man was about 20 years old. He said, “I left my wife young and I was only married for a night or two or a week. Then I left. My wife, ḥarām, she has fallen in love with someone. She has taken him in his, I mean in her arms.”

He pulled out his knife, his blade to cut off the young man’s head. But then he thought of what he had been told and said, “Everything has its time. A matter like this does not get done in a hurry, I mean, leave everything to its time. Things do not come in a hurry.

First learn what the woman reports and was the young man reports. Who this could be?” He said, “I am going to sleep in that room and I will learn everything from them in the morning. If he is engaged to her, I will kill her, and if he is not engaged to her, I will not touch her.” He went to that room and slept.

In the morning his wife was welcoming him, “Welcome, father of so-and-so.” He was astonished. Who is the father of so-and-so? Let’s say, the boy, who was in her arms, was named ʕAli. “Welcome, father of ʕAli, welcome, Abu ʕAli!” He said, “What is this, she is saying Abu ʕAli to me? Who the hell is ʕAli?”

She said “ʕAli is my son. I did not see you at night. When did you arrive? Since you came at night, he was sleeping in my arms, didn’t you see us?” He said, “ʕAli is your son?” She said, “Yes.” He said, “Well, I had already pulled out the knife to cut off his head, but then I thought of my words that everything has a time and should not come in a hurry.”
He said, “This was the third advice.” All the advices were useful for him, the advices he had bought on the way with money; he made more money from them than they had cost.
